The year '''1605 in [[music]]''' involved some significant events.
==Events== *''none listed''
==Publications== *[[William Byrd]] – ''Gradualia'', book one *[[Claudio Monteverdi]] – {{Lang-it|Il quinto libro de madrigali a cinque voci di Claudio Monteverdi Maestro della Musica del Serenissimo Sig.r Duca di Mantoa, col basso continuo per il Clavicembano, Chittarone, od altro simile istromento; fatto particolarmente per li sei ultimi, per li altri a beneplacito}} (fifth book of [[Madrigal (music)|madrigals]] ''a''5), published in [[Venice]] *[[Michael Praetorius]] – ''Musae Sionae'', Part 1 *[[Tomás Luis de Victoria]] – ''[[Officium Defunctorum (Victoria)|Officium Defunctorum]], sex vocibus, in obitu et obsequiis sacrae imperatricis''
==Classical music==
==Opera== *''none listed''
==Births== *March – [[Antonio Bertali]], Italian composer (died 1669) *April – [[Giacomo Carissimi]], composer (died 1674) *[[April 19]] – [[Orazio Benevoli]], composer (died 1672) *[[July 9]] – [[Simon Dach]], hymn-writer (died 1659) *[[September 17]] – [[Francesco Sacrati]], early opera composer (died 1650) *''date unknown'' – [[Constantia Zierenberg]], singer and musician (died 1653) *''probable'' **[[Johann Vierdanck]], violinist, cornettist, and composer (died 1646) **[[Julius Johann Weiland]], composer (died 1663)
==Deaths== *[[February 19]] – [[Orazio Vecchi]], Italian composer (born 1550) *[[September 24]] – [[Manuel Mendes]], composer and music teacher (born c. 1547) *''date unknown'' – [[Pedro Bermúdez]], composer and chapel-master (born 1558)
{{DEFAULTSORT:1605 In Music}} [[Category:1605|Music]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

'''ArtWatch International''' was founded by [[James Beck (art historian)|James Beck]], [[professor]] of [[art history]] at [[Columbia University]], to monitor, and campaign for better practices in, the conservation of art works. The United Kingdom branch, '''ArtWatch UK''', is run by Michael Daley.
==Activities==
In 1991, Beck criticised the cleaning of [[Jacopo della Quercia]]'s sculpture, the tomb of Ilaria del Carretto in [[Lucca]] cathedral in [[Italy]]. As a result, the conservator sued him for "aggravated slander", which carries a possible three-year prison sentence. Beck won the case and subsequently co-founded ArtWatch.<ref name=memoriam>"In Memoriam", ''The Art Newspaper'', July/August 2007.</ref>
ArtWatch has been critical of many conservation practices and projects, including the restoration of [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s [[The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)|''The Last Supper'']] and the [[restoration of the Sistine Chapel frescoes]]. In 2004, it raised an unsuccessful petition to halt the restoration of [[Michelangelo]]'s ''[[David (Michelangelo)|David]]'', which has since been found to be developing cracks.
ArtWatch UK have included a commemorative issue on the late James Beck; a report on the damage to artworks in transit for blockbuster exhibitions; and articles critical of the results of restorations on modern painters like [[Gustav Klimt]]. The November 2008 ArtWatch UK journal contained 20 articles campaigning about developments in the UNESCO-protected city of [[Saint Petersburg]].
Beck was, and Daley is, frequently outspoken and their opinions on recent restorations have been covered regularly by the press.<ref>[http://www.ukic.org.uk/members/news.html ukic.org]</ref><ref>[http://www.artwatchinternational.org/db_images/pdfs/RaphaelPinksTimes19Oct2004.mht artwatchinternational.org] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051231025337/http://www.artwatchinternational.org/db_images/pdfs/RaphaelPinksTimes19Oct2004.mht |date=December 31, 2005 }}</ref> However, they have been equally strongly opposed by those they criticise. The Surveyor of the Fabric of [[St. Paul's Cathedral]], who oversaw a 2004 cleaning of the cathedral that came under fire by Daley, retorted that "ArtWatch UK sounds very grand, but seems to be the view of one person."<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/printFriendly/0,,1-7-1139770,00.html ''The Times'']</ref> The investigation of the restoration campaign had been conducted and written by art historian, Florence Hallett.{{citation needed|date=November 2008}}
==Ludwig Burchard== In April 2006 the ArtWatch UK Journal published research into Ludwig Burchard, a scholar who had made many attributions to [[Peter Paul Rubens|Rubens]]. This showed that Burchard had been prepared to make false attributions for commercial gain. It again called into question the authenticity of the [[National Gallery (London)|National Gallery]]'s ''[[Samson and Delilah (Rubens)|Samson and Delilah]]''—and the integrity of the then director [[Neil MacGregor]]. The research was conducted by Dr. [[Kasia Pisarek]].
==See also== *[[Art conservation and restoration]] *[[Frank Herbert Mason]] Artwatch activist and artist
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.artwatchinternational.org ArtWatch International web site] *[http://artwatchuk.wordpress.com ArtWatch UK web site] *[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2010/dec/12/leonardo-da-vinci-poland-damage Guardian article on a Leonardo at risk]

{{Refimprove|date=January 2008}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Artists United Against Apartheid | background = group_or_band | genre = Various-rock, hip hop, jazz | years_active = 1985 | label = [[EMI]] | past_members = Various
Founded by [[Steven Van Zandt]] }} {{International opposition to Apartheid}} '''Artists United Against Apartheid''' was a 1985 protest group founded by [[activism|activist]] and performer [[Steven Van Zandt]] and record producer [[Arthur Baker (musician)|Arthur Baker]] to protest [[apartheid]] in [[South Africa]]. The group produced the song "[[Sun City (song)|Sun City]]" and the album ''[[Sun City (album)|Sun City]]'' that year, which is considered a notable [[Music in the movement against apartheid|anti-apartheid song]].{{cite web|author=Times LIVE |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/entertainment/music/2014/04/28/seven-great-anti-apartheid-songs-videos |title=Seven great anti-apartheid songs: Videos |publisher=Times LIVE |date= |accessdate=2016-10-24}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/dec/05/entertainment/la-et-ms-nelson-mandela-dies-music-ten-essential-antiapartheid-songs-20130627 |title=Nelson Mandela and music: Ten essential anti-Apartheid songs - latimes |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=December 5, 2013 |accessdate=2016-10-24}} ==Sun City== [[Sun City, North West|Sun City]] was a place where the South African government allowed entertainment that was banned in most of the country. In protest of apartheid, an international boycott by performers continued for years, although some, such as [[Queen (band)|Queen]], ignored it. ==Writing and recording== Van Zandt became interested in writing a song about Sun City to make parallels with the plight of Native Americans. [[Danny Schechter]], a journalist who was then working with [[ABC News]]' ''[[20/20 (US television series)|20/20]]'', suggested turning the song into a different kind of "[[We Are the World]]", or as Schechter explains, "a song about change not charity, freedom not famine."{{ref}} When Van Zandt was finished writing "[[Sun City (song)|Sun City]]", he, Schechter and producer Arthur Baker spent the next several months searching for artists to participate in the project. Van Zandt initially declined to invite Springsteen, not wanting to take advantage of their friendship, but Schechter had no problem asking and Springsteen accepted the invitation. Van Zandt was also shy about calling legendary jazz artist [[Miles Davis]]. Schechter initiated the contact and Davis also accepted. Eventually, Van Zandt, Baker and Schechter would gather an array of artists, described by rock critic [[Dave Marsh]] as "the most diverse line up of popular musicians ever assembled for a single session"[[Dave Marsh|Marsh, Dave]] & Bernard, James (1994) New Book of Rock Lists Fireside 1230 Avenue of the Americas, New York NY 10020 {{ISBN|0-671-78700-4}}., including [[Kool DJ Herc]], [[Grandmaster Melle Mel]], [[Ruben Blades]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Pat Benatar]], [[Herbie Hancock]], [[Ringo Starr]] and his son [[Zak Starkey]], [[Lou Reed]], [[Run–D.M.C.]], [[Peter Gabriel]], [[Bob Geldof]], [[Clarence Clemons]], [[David Ruffin]], [[Eddie Kendricks]], [[Darlene Love]], [[Bobby Womack]], [[Afrika Bambaataa]], [[Kurtis Blow]], [[The Fat Boys]], [[Jackson Browne]], [[Daryl Hannah]], [[Peter Wolf]], [[Bono]], [[George Clinton (funk musician)|George Clinton]], [[Keith Richards]], [[Ronnie Wood]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], [[Hall & Oates]], [[Jimmy Cliff]], [[Big Youth]], [[Michael Monroe]], [[Stiv Bators]], [[Peter Garrett]], [[Ron Carter]], [[Ray Barretto]], [[Gil Scott-Heron]], [[Nona Hendryx]], [[Kashif]], [[Lotti Golden]], [[Lakshminarayana Shankar]] and [[Joey Ramone]].{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/sun-city-artists-united-against-apartheid-mw0000200232/credits|title=Sun City: Artists United Against Apartheid - Various Artists / Credits|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate= September 12, 2018}} These artists also vowed never to perform at Sun City, because to do so would in their minds seem to be an acceptance of apartheid. Schechter had also taken on the job of documenting the sessions on video and producing a behind-the-scenes documentary, working with 16 mm crews and independent production companies, directed by [[Jonathan Demme]]. Paul "Lucky" Goldberg, director, producer and cinematographer for ThunderVision Media Ltd and president of Hollywood New York International since 1993, worked with producer and partner Paul Allen of ThunderVision Media Ltd, based in New York at [[Kaufman Astoria Studios]] to capture the action. Lucky and Paul introduced a new camera technology to work alongside the 16mm crews, the one-piece camera - [[Panasonic]]'s Recam format for extensive handheld coverage of two days of the artists in the streets of Manhattan as well as a rendition of "Sun City" in [[Washington Square Park]]. Approximately 150 policemen surrounded the entire park on horseback and foot to secure the area for the performance, which included Van Zandt, [[Bono]], Springsteen, [[the Fat Boys]], [[Mötley Crüe]], Afrika Bambaataa, Nona Hendryx and many others. One of the most notable shots was caught when Bono gave a huge kiss on the cheek to one of the Fat Boys, in his signature yellow satin jacket and red hat. They went on to shoot Sun City II in [[Central Park]], capturing the politics and music of the spirit of Little Steven's award-winning "Sun City", including interviews with Peter Gabriel and Bono. Schechter invited [[MTV]] to get involved and asked a friend, Hart Perry, to film the sessions. During the course of the film, Schechter asks the artists to explain their involvement in the project in their own words: "Sun City's become a symbol of a society which is very oppressive and denies basic rights to the majority of its citizens," said Jackson Browne. "In a sense, Sun City is also a symbol of that society's 'right' to entertain itself in any way that it wants to, to basically try to buy us off and to buy off world opinion." Recalls Schechter, "I was surprised that many of the best-known rock 'n rollers were so publicity shy. Most of them had publicists who staged their media appearances. They weren't used to cameras poking them in the face. Bruce Springsteen at first turned down my request for an interview, but just as I was walking away from him dejected, he ran after me and agreed to say a few words for the documentary. "When Miles started improvising in the studio...Steven and [[Arthur Baker (musician)|Arthur [Baker]]] insisted I not approach him with a camera. 'It's Miles, man," Baker said. "He's erratic, idiosyncratic, explosive. Wild. Don't mess with him when he's playing...' I barged into the booth while Davis was setting up, introduced myself and asked if we could videotape him. Through the glass I could see Steve and Arthur, heads in hands, convinced that I had blown it. Miles smiled. 'Bring it on,' he ordered, 'bring it on.' And we did, getting priceless footage in the bargain." In addition to "Sun City," a number of other songs were recorded, making up the album ''[[Sun City (album)|Sun City]]''. ==Release== For a time Van Zandt and Baker were making the record without a record company or any outside financial support. Van Zandt financed much of it while producer [[Arthur Baker (musician)|Arthur Baker]] (notable for his work with [[Afrika Bambaataa]] and [[New Order (band)|New Order]]) donated studio time. Manhattan Records, under Bruce Lundvall's direction, came on board, acquiring rights to the recording and enabling Van Zandt and Baker to pay some of the bills. A committed record company attorney, the late Rick Dutka, also donated his time, along with noted music industry attorney, the late Owen Epstein as well as Van Zandt's assistant, Zoë Yanakis. Also, some New York's top recording engineers, studio musicians and recording studios donated their time as well as the artists who participated in recording Sun City. As well as lead vocals provided by notable artists [[Bruce Springsteen]], [[Bono]], [[Darlene Love]], [[Run DMC]], [[Lou Reed]], [[Eddie Kendricks]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], [[Nona Hendryx]] and others, the signature background vocal sound was created by [[Lotti Golden]], B.J.Nelson and Tina B.{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Artists-United-Against-Apartheid-Sun-City/release/5991679|title=Artists United Against Apartheid - Sun City|website=[[Discogs]]|accessdate=12 September 2018}} Schechter's connections with ABC News posed some risks. "I couldn't tell ABC what I was doing on the side," recalls Schechter. "They would not have approved. I knew I couldn't propose a story about Sun City either, because I had stepped over the line and become part of the story. I tried and mostly succeeded in keeping my name out of the papers and my mug out of the video. I was terrified that [[20/20 (US television series)|20/20]] would dump me if they knew what I was doing, especially if my affiliation with ABC was dragged into it, even though the network had nothing to do with the project. I worked even harder at ABC, producing more stories than many of my colleagues, so I couldn't be accused of slacking off." {{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/40759595|title=The more you watch, the less you know : news wars/(sub)merged hopes/media adventures|last=Danny |first=Schechter |date=1999|publisher=Seven Stories Press|isbn=1888363800|edition=Rev. and updated|location=New York|oclc=40759595}} ==Reaction== ===Song=== The song "Sun City" was only a modest success in the US, reaching #38 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot 100 chart in December 1985. Only about half of American radio stations played "Sun City,"{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} with some objecting to the lyrics' explicit criticism of President [[Ronald Reagan]]'s policy of "[[constructive engagement]]." Meanwhile, "Sun City" was a major success in countries where there was little or no radio station resistance to the record or its messages, reaching [[Kent Music Report|#4]] in Australia, [[RPM (magazine)|#10]]{{cite journal | url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?&file_num=nlc008388.0625&volume=43&issue=18&issue_dt=January%2025%201986&type=1&interval=24&PHPSESSID=c4ao5klg6bn7uptptp2uf0tvt2 | title=Top Singles | journal=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]] | year=January 25, 1986 | volume=43 | issue=18 | publisher=[[Library and Archives Canada]] | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011092534/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?&file_num=nlc008388.0625&volume=43&issue=18&issue_dt=January%2025%201986&type=1&interval=24&PHPSESSID=c4ao5klg6bn7uptptp2uf0tvt2 | archivedate= October 11, 2012 |deadurl=yes}} in Canada and [[UK Singles Chart|#21]] in the UK.{{cite book | first= David | last= Roberts | year= 2006 | title= British Hit Singles & Albums | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | page= 31}} The song was banned in South Africa. ===Documentary=== Van Zandt and Schechter also struggled to get the documentary seen. [[Public Broadcasting Service]] (PBS) refused to broadcast the [[non-profit]] film [http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x2zheo_lou-reed-little-stevie-making-of-su_travel "The Making of Sun City"] even though it won the [[International Documentary Association]]'s top honors in 1986; PBS claimed the featured artists were also involved in making the film and were therefore "self-promoting."{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} (In contrast, PBS chose to broadcast ''The Making of "[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]"'', which was made as a promotional exercise by the for-profit [[Paramount Pictures]] and [[Lucasfilm|Lucasfilm Ltd.]]) In 1987, [[WNYC-TV]], the New York City-owned [[public television]] station, aired an updated version of the documentary, produced by filmmaker [[Bill Lichtenstein]] along with Schechter. The film included updates about the Sun City resort and apartheid as well as the success of the Sun City video. In addition to airing the documentary, WNYC-TV made the film available over the PBS system to public television stations across the country for broadcast. ===Overall impact=== The album and single raised more than a million U.S. dollars for anti-apartheid projects. It premiered at the [[United Nations]], thanks to the Special Committee Against Apartheid and UN officers such as [[Aracelly Santana]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} The record never achieved the financial success of "[[We Are the World]]," although [[Oliver Tambo]] and the ANC's school in [[Tanzania]] "was sure happy when we gave them a big check," according to Schechter. In South Africa, "Sun City" would later inspire musician [[Johnny Clegg]] to create a local organization similar to Van Zandt's, and "Sun City" also became the catalyst for the ''South Africa Now'' TV series. ==Post-apartheid== With the end of the apartheid regime in 1994 and the reintegration of Sun City and other former nominally-independent regions into the South African state, "Sun City" ceased to be a contemporary protest and became a historical document. In 1997, the man who created Sun City, [[Sol Kerzner]], came to the United States to build the [[Mohegan Sun]], a Native American gambling casino. {{Portal|1980s}} ==References== {{note|myw}}''The More You Watch, The Less You Know'' by Danny Schechter ==External links== * The [[African Activist Archive]] Project website includes documents, photographs and audio related to [http://africanactivist.msu.edu/organization.php?name=Artists+United+Against+Apartheid Artists United Against Apartheid] {{Steven Van Zandt}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:International opposition to apartheid in South Africa]] [[Category:Anti-racism]] [[Category:Political art]] [[Category:Musical advocacy groups]] [[Category:Steven Van Zandt]] [[Category:EMI Records artists]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1985]] [[Category:Music in the movement against apartheid]]

{{Infobox settlement |official_name = Dallas Arts District |nickname = |image_skyline = |image_caption = Overview of the District |image_flag = |image_seal = |image_map = Dallas, Texas map - Arts District.svg |map_caption = Location in [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] |subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] |subdivision_name = United States |subdivision_type1 = [[U.S. state|State]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Texas]] |subdivision_type2 = [[List of Texas counties|Counties]] |subdivision_name2 = [[Dallas County, Texas|Dallas]] |subdivision_type3 = City |subdivision_name3 = [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] |subdivision_type4 = Area |subdivision_name4 = [[downtown Dallas|Downtown]] |area_total_km2 = 0.28 |area_total_sq_mi = 0.11 |area_land_km2 = 0.28 |area_land_sq_mi = 0.11 |area_water_km2 = 0.0 |area_water_sq_mi = 0.0 |area_water_percent = 0 |population_as_of = |population_note = |population_total = |population_density_km2 = |elevation_ft = 459 |elevation_m = 140 |postal_code_type = ZIP code |postal_code = 75201, 75202 |area_code = [[Area code 214|214]], [[Area code 469|469]], [[Area code 972|972]] |website = {{URL|http://thedallasartsdistrict.org/}} |footnotes = }} The '''Arts District''' is a performing and visual arts district in [[Downtown Dallas]], [[Texas]]. It is located south of [[State Thomas, Dallas, Texas|State Thomas]]; southeast of [[Uptown Dallas|Uptown]]; north of the [[City Center District, Dallas, Texas|City Center District]]; west of [[Bryan Place, Dallas, Texas|Bryan Place]]; and east of the [[West End Historic District, Dallas, Texas|West End Historic District]]. It is bounded by St. Paul Street, Ross Avenue, [[Texas State Highway Spur 366|Spur 366]] ([[Woodall Rodgers Freeway]]), and the [[U.S. Highway 75 (Texas)|US 75]]/[[Interstate 45 (Texas)|I-45]] (unsigned [[Interstate 345 (Texas)|I-345]]) elevated freeway ([[Central Expressway (Dallas)|Central Expressway]]). (Previously the district extended east only to Routh Street, but a 9 March 2005 [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] City Council approval extended it east to I-345.)''[http://www.dallasnews.com The Dallas Morning News]'' - 9 March 2005. "[http://forum.dallasmetropolis.com/showpost.php?p=59681&postcount=353 Council approves Arts District expansion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708222413/http://forum.dallasmetropolis.com/showpost.php?p=59681&postcount=353 |date=2011-07-08 }}" by Emily Ramshaw. ([http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/031005dnmetcouncil.49a6c.html Original Location of article].) Retrieved 1 January 2007. The Arts District is the founder and member of the [[Global Cultural Districts Network]]. The district is 68 [[acre]]s (0.28 km²) large and is home to some of Dallas’ most significant cultural landmarks including facilities for visual, performing, and developing arts. {{citation needed|date=October 2011}} == Arts District Venues == [[File:Downtown Dallas Arts District.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Pictured in the foreground is the [[Winspear Opera House]] with its reflecting pool and the [[Meyerson Symphony Center]], both located within the Dallas Arts District.]] The Arts District is home to 13 facilities and organizations including The Annette Strauss Artist Square, the Belo Mansion/Dallas Bar Association, Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts, Cathedral Shrine of the Virgin of Guadalupe, Dallas Black Dance Theatre, Dallas Museum of Art, Dallas Symphony Orchestra, Dallas Theater Center, Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center, Nasher Sculpture Center, St. Paul United Methodist Church, Fellowship Church, Trammell Crow Center, and the Trammell & Margaret Crow Collection of Asian Art. In addition, multiple other organizations perform in the District on an ongoing basis. This includes everything from concerts to outdoor festivals, to lectures, youth education programs, and more. * [[AT&T Performing Arts Center]] ** [[Annette Strauss Artist Square]] ** [[Dee and Charles Wyly Theatre]] ** [[Margot and Bill Winspear Opera House]] * [[Moody Performance Hall]] * [[Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts]] * [[The Trammell & Margaret Crow Collection of Asian Art]] * [[Dallas Museum of Art]] * [[Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center]] * [[Nasher Sculpture Center]] * [[Klyde Warren Park]] == Other Structures == {{Div col|rules=yes}} * [[Belo Mansion]] / [[Dallas Bar Association|Dallas]] [[Bar associations|Bar Association]] * [[Cathedral Santuario de Guadalupe]] * [[Dallas Black Dance Theatre]] (formerly the Moorland YMCA) * [[Fellowship Church]] (Downtown Campus) * [[Trammell Crow Center]] * [[Klyde Warren Park]] * [[St. Paul United Methodist Church (Dallas)|St. Paul United Methodist Church]] {{Div col end}} == Transportation == === Trains === ==== Light Rail ==== * '''[[Dallas Area Rapid Transit|DART]]''': {{DART B}}, {{DART R}}, {{DART G}}, and {{DART O}} ** [[St. Paul (DART station)|St. Paul Station]] (''in [[City Center District, Dallas, Texas|City Center District]]'') ** [[Pearl Station]] (''in [[City Center District, Dallas, Texas|City Center District]]'') ==== Streetcars ==== * [[McKinney Avenue Transit Authority]] M-Line runs from McKinney Avenue south down St. Paul Street to Federal Street, east along Federal to Olive Street, and north on Olive back up to McKinney.{{cite web|url=http://www.mata.org/schedulesroutemap.html|title=Trolley, McKinney Avenue Transit Authority, M-Line, Dallas, TX Schedules & Route Map|author=|date=|website=www.mata.org|accessdate=22 April 2018}} === Highways === * [[File:Texas Spur 366.svg|20px]] [[Texas State Highway Spur 366|Spur 366]] (Woodall Rodgers Freeway) * [[File:US 75.svg|20px]] [[U.S. Highway 75 (Texas)|US 75]] [[Central Expressway (Dallas)|Central Expressway]]/[[File:I-45.svg|20px]] [[Interstate 45 (Texas)|I-45]] connection (unsigned [[File:I-345.svg|20px]] [[Interstate 345 (Texas)|I-345]]) == Education == [[File:Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts.jpg|thumb|right|260px|[[Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts]]]] The Arts District is served by the [[Dallas Independent School District]]. One school, the [[Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts]], is located in the Arts District. Residents of the Arts District north and east of Akard Street are zoned to [[Sam Houston Elementary School (McAllen, Texas)|Sam Houston Elementary School]]. Residents south and west of Akard are zoned to [[Hope Medrano Elementary School]]. All Arts District residents are zoned to [[Thomas J. Rusk Middle School]] and [[North Dallas High School]].[http://www.dallasisd.org/ Dallas ISD] - [http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/indexfeeder.htm 2006 School Feeder Patterns] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070409160022/http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/indexfeeder.htm |date=2007-04-09 }} - [http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/feeder2006/ndallas.htm North Dallas High School] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205180540/http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/feeder2006/ndallas.htm |date=2007-02-05 }}. (Maps: '''ES:''' [http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/eszones2006/Houston2006.pdf Houston] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620082855/http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/eszones2006/Houston2006.pdf |date=June 20, 2007 }}, [http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/eszones2006/Medrano2006.pdf Medrano] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620082858/http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/eszones2006/Medrano2006.pdf |date=2007-06-20 }}; '''MS:''' [http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/midzones2006/Rusk2006.pdf Rusk] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620082857/http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/midzones2006/Rusk2006.pdf |date=2007-06-20 }}; '''HS:''' [http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/highzones2006/NorthDallas2006.pdf North Dallas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620082900/http://www.dallasisd.org/eval/schoolinfo/highzones2006/NorthDallas2006.pdf |date=2007-06-20 }}.) Retrieved 31 December 2006. ==Gallery== File:Winspear Opera House 18 auditorium.jpg|Interior of [[Margot and Bill Winspear Opera House]]. File:Morton H Meyerson Symphony Center.jpg|The [[Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center]] File:Dallas Cathedral.jpg|[[Cathedral Santuario de Guadalupe]], Dallas Arts District File:Downtown Dallas TX 2013-06-08 067.jpg|The [[Dallas Museum of Art]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{stack|{{Portal|Dallas}}}} {{Downtown Dallas labelled map|float=right}} *[http://thedallasartsdistrict.org/ Dallas Arts District] *[http://www.attpac.org/ AT&T Center for the Performing Arts] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060309200843/http://www.dallasisd.org/btw/ Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20010404010044/http://www.dallasmuseumofart.org/ Dallas Museum Of Art] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050206130313/http://www.mhmsc.com/ Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center] *[http://www.nashersculpturecenter.org/ Nasher Sculpture Center] *[http://www.artsmagnet.org/ Booker T. Washington School for the Visual and Performing Arts Advisory Board] {{Downtown Dallas}} {{Dallas Neighborhoods|selected=downtown}} {{Dallas}} {{Coord|32|47|21.57|N|96|47|53.88|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Arts in Dallas]] [[Category:Arts districts]] [[Category:Downtown Dallas]]

revision.text:
{{Sex in SF mini}}
'''Broad Universe''' is a [[United States]]-based, all volunteer organization with the primary goal of promoting [[science fiction]], [[fantasy]], and [[horror fiction|horror]] written by women. Writers, editors, publishers, reviewers, artists, and [[science fiction fandom|fans]] are invited to join them. "Broad-minded" men are welcome to participate. The organization originated in a panel discussion at [[WisCon]], the feminist [[science fiction convention]] in [[Madison, Wisconsin|Madison]], [[Wisconsin]], in 2000.
Broad Universe created the Rapid Fire Reading with a small group of member authors who each read an excerpt from their work no more than 5 minutes long. This has been very popular at conventions. It gives more authors an opportunity to read and it gives the audience a taste of fantastic fiction from several authors instead of just one.
Broad Universe buys dealer's tables at various conventions (genre related or publishers, librarians and other conventions of use to the members.) One member benefit is the sale of their books at 0% commission by Broad Universe volunteers at conventions.
== See also == * [[Female science fiction authors]] * [[Feminist science fiction]] * [[James Tiptree, Jr. Award]] * [[Sex and sexuality in speculative fiction]] * [[Women in speculative fiction]]
==External links== * [http://www.broaduniverse.org/ Broad Universe website] * [http://wiki.feministsf.net feminist science fiction wiki]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Orphan|date=September 2014}} {{Sources|date=April 2015}} '''Croatia Association of Theatre Critics and Theatre Scholars''' (HDKKT) is a professional, nonprofit organization.
== History == The association was founded on 22 October 1975 at founding assembly in [[Zagreb]] and registered into Civil Association Register on 9 March 1976.
HDKKT is a member of International Association of Theatre Critics (AICT/IACT) and collaborates with The International Federation for Theatre Research (FITR/IFTR). It was founded with goal to develop and promote quality of the profession, cooperation with other similar associations and theatres in [[Croatia]] and abroad and to protect [[Morality|moral]] and material interests of its members. The associations structure comprises: Assembly, Executive Committee and President, Supervisory Committee and Court of Honour. Association first resides in Ilica 42 and later in Amruševa Street 19, Zagreb. It has about 50 active members and 15 retired and since 2013 dance critics are also admitted.
Association is funded by [[Ministry of Culture (Croatia)|Ministry of Culture]]. Shortly after foundation, HDKKT launched Theatrology Library (Teatrologijska biblioteka) with Nikola Batušić as editor in chief and from1979 till 1992 thirty-three titles were published. In year 1994 Theatrology Library merged with Library Prolog (Biblioteka Prolog), former CKD, which was inherited by [http://www.agm.hr/ AGM] (Zagreb). The new library was named Actor′s Booklet Prolog (Glumišna knjižnica Prolog) with editorial board: Nikola Batušić, Branko Hećimović and Igor Mrduljaš. From 1992 till 1997 library published eleven books in cooperation with AGM after which AGM completely took over the publishing activities.
In 80′s association introduced the Award for the Best Play of the Season through members′ survey.
== Demeter's Award ==
Since 2012 HDKKT awards [http://www.hdkkt.hr/index.php/demetrova-nagrada Demeter's Award] for Lifetime Achievement. First one was awarded to one of the founders of HDKKT, president, historian and theatrologist [http://info.hazu.hr/bhecimovic_biography_en Branko Hećimović] 2012, second to secretary general, president, critic and theatrologist [[:hr:Igor Mrduljaš|Igor Mrduljaš]] 2013 and the third to theatrologist, critic, educator and President of HDKKT [[:hr:Boris Senker|Boris Senker]]. The Demeter's Award is awarded on the day of publication of first [[:hr:Dimitrija Demeter|Demeter′s]] criticism about the first professional play in Croatian language Juran i Sofija by [[:hr:Ivan Kukuljević Sakcinski|Ivan Kukuljević Sakcinski]] in journal [[:hr:Danica (časopis)|Danica ilirska]] on 13 July 1840 which is considered the beginning of the Croatian theatre criticism.<ref>[http://www.hdkkt.hr/index.php/demetrova-nagrada Croatian Association of Theatre Critics and for Theatre Research: Demeter's Award for Lifetime Achievement], 11 July 2014</ref>
=== List of Awardees=== * 2012 [http://info.hazu.hr/bhecimovic_biography_en Branko Hećimović] * 2013 [[:hr:Igor Mrduljaš|Igor Mrduljaš]] * 2014 [[:hr:Boris Senker|Boris Senker]] * 2015 [[:hr:Boris_B._Hrovat|Boris B. Hrovat]] * 2016. [[:hr:Vlatko_Perković|Vlatko Perković]] * 2017. [http://info.hazu.hr/hr/clanovi_akademije/osobne_stranice/abognersaban/abognersaban_biografija/ Antonija Bogner Šaban]
== Managing Authority ==
=== Executive Committee === [[Sanja Nikčević]] - President, [[:hr:Alen_Biskupović|Alen Biskupović]] Secretary General, Mira Muhoberac, Antonija Bogner Šaban, Martina Petranović
=== Supervisory Committee === Andrija Tunjić, Goran Ivanišević, Anđela Vidović
=== Court of Honour === Boris Senker, Olga Vujović, Tomislav Kurelec
== Former Presidents and Secretary Generals ==
=== Presidents === [[:hr:Petar Selem|Petar Selem]] (1976-1980), [http://info.hazu.hr/bhecimovic_biography_en Branko Hećimović] (1980-1982), [http://www.enciklopedija.hr/Natuknica.aspx?ID=23339 Marija Grgičević] (1982-1984), [[:hr:Boris Senker|Boris Senker]] (1984-1988), [[:hr:Nedjeljko Fabrio|Nedjeljko Fabrio]] (1988-1991), [[:hr:Mani Gotovac|Mani Gotovac]] (1991-1993), [http://info.hazu.hr/abognersaban_biography_en Antonija Bogner Šaban] (1993-2001), [[:hr:Boris B. Hrovat|Boris B. Hrovat]] (2001-2005), [[:hr:Igor Mrduljaš|Igor Mrduljaš]] (2005-2010) and [[:hr:Sanja Nikčević|Sanja Nikčević]] (2010 - ).
=== Secretary Generals === Giga Gračan (1976-1978), [[:hr:Igor Mrduljaš|Igor Mrduljaš]], Branko Vukšić (1991-1993), [[:hr:Ana Lederer|Ana Lederer]] (1993-2001), [[:hr:Sanja Nikčević|Sanja Nikčević]] (2001-2010), Ljubica Anđelković (2010-2012), Lidija Zozoli (2012 till 13 June 2014), [https://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=251888004&trk=nav_responsive_tab_profile Alen Biskupović] (since 13 June 2014 - )

[[Image:Torre da Paz.jpg|thumb|PL Peace Tower]] {{nihongo|'''Dai Heiwa Kinen Tō'''|[[:ja:大平和祈念塔|大平和祈念塔]]}}, lit. ''The Great Peace Prayer Tower'', is a [[cenotaph]] tower in [[Tondabayashi, Osaka]], [[Japan]].
== General == The official name of the cenotaph tower is literally {{nihongo|"non-denominational [lit.: above denominations] war victims great cenotaph tower to pray peace"|超宗派万国戦争犠牲者慰霊大平和祈念塔|Chōshūha Bankoku Sensō Giseisha irei dai heiwa kinen tō}}. The tower is 180 m in height, white in color, and built by the [[PL Kyodan|Church of Perfect Liberty]] in August 1970.
The [[cenotaph]] is designated for the [[soul]]s of all war victims in [[history]], regardless of [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[ethnic group]], [[sovereign state]], [[border]], [[region]], [[religion]], [[religious denomination]] and [[creed]]. The cenotaph is also used as a [[tomb]] for unidentified war victims. A ceremony and memorial service, where participants pray for world peace, is held annually on 1 August.
== See also == * [[Chidorigafuchi National Cemetery]] * [[Ryozen Kannon]] * [[Sekai Munei Senshi no Haka]] * [[PL Kyodan|Church of Perfect Liberty]]
== External links == *{{commons category-inline|Great Peace Prayer Tower}} * [http://www.perfect-liberty.or.jp/heiwato.html 超宗派万国戦争犠牲者慰霊大平和祈念塔] (in Japanese)

{{multiple issues| {{advert|date=September 2013}} {{notability|Organizations|date=September 2013}} }}
'''Developing Lives''' is a photography program run for residents of the [[New York City Housing Authority]] or [[New York City Housing Authority|NYCHA]], a [[government agency]] that provides [[public housing]] for low and moderate residents throughout the [[Borough (New York City)|five boroughs]] of [[New York City]].<ref name=Studio>{{cite web|title=Developing Lives: Studio NYCHA|url=http://studionycha.org/developinglives/|publisher=NYCHA|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref>
The program provides workshops by NYCHA using privately donated film cameras and laptops along with discounted film development.<ref name=Studio /> Private support of NYCHA programs is welcome given the agency experiencing huge shortfalls in operating and capital funding.<ref name=Committee>{{cite web|last=Committee on Public Housing|title=Testimony from NYCHA Chairman John B. Rhea|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/nycha/downloads/pdf/2013-preliminary-budget-testimony-3-12-13-final.pdf|publisher=NYC.gov|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref> The participants create a visual and [[oral history]] of daily life that differs from a common media portrayal of NYC housing projects.<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite web|last=Sandhu|first=Sukhdev|title=Film reviews: American Gangster and Brick Lane|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmreviews/3669300/Film-reviews-American-Gangster-and-Brick-Lane.html|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=20 August 2013|date=16 Nov 2007}}</ref><ref name=Catsoulis>{{cite web|last=Catsoulis|first=Jeanette|title=On One Corner of America, the Violent Realities of Thug Life- ‘Player Hating,’ Maggie Hadleigh-West’s Documentary|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2012/04/06/movies/player-hating-maggie-hadleigh-wests-documentary.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&_r=0|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=Rosenbaum>{{cite web|last=Rosenbaum|first=Jonathan|title=Film Search: Candyman|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/candyman/Film?oid=1059252|publisher=Chicago Reader|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref><ref name=Wilson>{{cite web|last=Wilson|first=Beth|title=Film: Harry Brown|url=http://www.trespassmag.com/film-harry-brown/|publisher=Trespass Magazine|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref> It may be that NYCHA hopes that Developing Lives can help change the image of those living in the projects.<ref name=Nguyen>{{cite web|last=Nguyen|first=Tuan|title=Manhattanville Houses residents give picture of their lives in photo exhibit|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/manhattanville-houses-residents-give-picture-lives-photo-exhibit-article-1.121673|publisher=NY Daily News|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref><ref name="Kodak Blog">{{cite web|title=The Kodak Sponsored "Developing Lives" Photography Program|url=http://1000words.kodak.com/2012/11/04/the-kodak-sponsored-developing-lives-photography-program/|work=Kodak Blog|publisher=Kodak|accessdate=5 September 2013}}</ref>
== History ==
Developing Lives began in the Housing Authority’s Manhattanville Development in fall 2010 with a handful of participants.<ref name="Nguyen"/> The program has by now included residents of 15 of the agency’s 334 developments. Meanwhile, over 10,000 viewers have seen the photographs online.<ref name=Brochure>{{cite web|title=Developing Lives Brochure|url=http://seeingforourselves.org/media/developing-lives-brochure.pdf|publisher=Seeing for Ourselves|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref>
Developing Lives was brought to NYCHA by former [[New York City Transit Authority|MTA]] executive [[George Carrano]] of the non-profit [[Seeing For Ourselves]], which also arranged the private partnerships behind the program.<ref name=Brochure /><ref name=Team>{{cite web|title=Developing Lives: Meet the Team|url=http://studionycha.org/developinglives/developing-lives-class-information/meet-the-team/|publisher=Studio NYCHA|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref> Carrano had served as curator of photography exhibits of war [[photojournalism]] and participatory photography that were lauded in the media as poignant<ref name=Salamon>{{cite news|last=Salamon|first=Julie|title=Child Photographers Show Lives of Hardship and Hope|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/10/arts/child-photographers-show-lives-of-hardship-and-hope.html|accessdate=20 August 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=July 10, 2004}}</ref> and not to be missed.<ref name=Art>{{cite news|last=The New York Time|title=Art Listings|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/30/arts/design/30art.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=20 August 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=September 30, 2005}}</ref> Chelsea Davis, founder of two participatory arts programs and with family roots in NYC public housing, directs the program. Lily Randall, former art instructor in St. Louis public housing, also helped run Developing Lives.<ref name="Kodak Blog" /><ref name=Team />
== Developing Lives as Photography ==
Developing Lives belongs to the school of participatory photography. This school turns the traditional photography paradigm on its head. Those whose normal role is limited to their function as objects of photography receive training to document their own lives. The movement originated in American efforts two decades ago to aid rural Chinese women, who had never used a camera, but now encompasses all efforts to take charge of one's own narrative using photography.<ref name=Brochure /> Milestones include the NYC exhibit Unbroken by [[Photovoice|PhotoVoice]], a group dedicated to this school of photography.<ref name=Brochure /><ref name="Salamon"/> George Carrano served as the show’s curator.<ref name="Kodak Blog" /><ref name=Team />
== The Program ==
Developing Lives includes weekly sessions in which instructors present a new [[Photography|photography technique]] (light, shadow, camera language, etc.) and introduce a well-known photographer whose work exemplifies that technical style. The program distributes single-use Kodak cameras at the start of every class which are returned the following week. The [[film]] is then processed and photographs reviewed and returned. Participants are asked to bear in mind the new photography technique when documenting their lives throughout the week.<ref name=Class>{{cite web|title=Developing Lives Class Information|url=http://studionycha.org/developinglives/developing-lives-class-information/|publisher=Studio NYCHA|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref>
In addition to teaching technical skills, Developing Lives also helps participants become [[Documentary film|documentary]] photographers. The classes discuss the art of [[storytelling]] through a photograph. All photographs are paired with handwritten captions from the photographer.<ref name=Class />
The Developing Lives photographs were combined with a narrative explaining the challenges faced by residents, and published as [[Project Lives]] in April 2015.
== References == {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Photography organizations]] [[Category:Public housing in New York City]] [[Category:Arts organizations based in New York City]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2010]] [[Category:2010 establishments in New York (state)]]

/* History */ fixed ISBN error message - source https://www.books-by-isbn.com/1-59030/1590301005-A-Handbook-of-Tibetan-Buddhist-Symbols-ROBERT-BEER-1-59030-100-5.html
revision.text:
{{distinguish|The Endless Not}} {{redirect|The Eternal Knot|the 2001 classical album|Adiemus IV: The Eternal Knot}} [[File:Endlessknot.svg|thumb|One common form of the Endless Knot]] [[File:Shrivatsa.JPG|thumb|More decorative]] [[File:Endless knot Red lacquerware dish Ming Dynasty.jpg|thumb|More complex form seen on ca. 400-year-old Chinese lacquerware dish.]]
The '''endless knot''' or '''eternal knot''' ({{lang-sa|[[śrīvatsa]]}}; [[Tibetic languages|Tibetan]] དཔལ་བེའུ། ''dpal be'u''; [[Mongolian language|Mongolian]] ''Ulzii'') is a symbolic [[knot (mathematics)|knot]] and one of the [[Ashtamangala|Eight Auspicious Symbols]]. It is an important cultural marker in places significantly influenced by [[Tibetan Buddhism]] such as [[Tibet]], [[Mongolia]], [[Tuva]], [[Kalmykia]], and [[Republic of Buryatia|Buryatia]]. It is also sometimes found in [[Chinese art]] and used in [[Chinese knotting|Chinese knots]].
== History == The endless knot symbol appears on clay tablets from the [[Indus Valley Civilization]] (2500 BC),<ref>Robert Beer (2003),The Handbook of Tibetan Buddhist Symbols, Serindia Publications, {{ISBN|1-59030-100-5}}</ref> and the same symbol also appears on an historic era inscription.<ref>Michael Danino (2010), Lost River: On The Trail of the Sarasvati,Penguin Books, {{ISBN|0143068644}}</ref>
== Interpretations == The endless knot has been described as "an ancient symbol representing the interweaving of the [[spirtuality|Spiritual]] path, the flowing of [[Time]] and Movement within That Which is [[Eternity|Eternal]]. All existence, it says, is bound by time and [[Impermanence|change]], yet ultimately rests serenely within the [[Divinity|Divine]] and the Eternal."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Anna |first=Christina |title=Ancient Symbols |url=http://www.pinterest.com/explore/ancient-symbols/?p=1 |publisher=pinterest.com |year=2012 |accessdate=2014-05-14}}</ref> Various interpretations of the symbol are:
* The eternal continuum of mind. * The endless knot iconography symbolised [[Samsara]] ''i.e.'', the endless cycle of suffering or birth, death and rebirth within Tibetan Buddhism. * The inter-twining of [[Wisdom in Buddhism|wisdom]] and [[metta|compassion]]. * Interplay and interaction of the opposing forces in the [[dualistic cosmology|dualistic]] world of manifestation, leading to their union, and ultimately to harmony in the universe. * The [[mutual dependence]] of [[religious doctrine]] and [[secular]] affairs. * The union of [[Wisdom in Buddhism|wisdom]] and [[Upasana|method]]. * The inseparability of [[emptiness]] ([[shunyata]]) and [[dependent origination]], the underlying [[reality]] of [[existence]]. * Symbolic of knot symbolism in linking [[ancestor]]s and [[omnipresence]] (refer etymology of [[Tantra]], [[Yoga]] and [[religion]]) (see [[Namkha]].) * Since the knot has no beginning or end it also symbolizes the [[wisdom]] of the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]].
== In other cultures == See [[7₄ knot]] for decorations or symbols in other cultures which are [[topological]]ly equivalent to the interlaced form of the simplest version of the Buddhist endless knot.<ref>{{Knot Atlas|7_4}}</ref>
== See also == {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Ashtamangala]] (also known as Eight Auspicious Symbols) * [[Celtic knot]] * [[Chinese knotting]] * [[Eternal return]] * [[Gordian knot]] * [[Indra's net]] * [[Islamic interlace patterns]] * [[Khachkar]]s – [[Armenia]]n knotwork * [[Knot garden]] * [[Knot theory]] * [[Mandala]] * [[Möbius strip]] * [[Namkha]] * [[Oseberg style]] * [[Ouroboros]] * [[Solomon's knot]] * [[Tantra]] * [[Three hares]] * [[Trefoil knot]] * [[Triquetra]] * [[Turk's head knot]] * [[Valknut]] * [[Yin and yang]] {{Div col end}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox museum | name = Flinders University Art Museum | image = | imagesize = | map_type = | latitude = | longitude = | established = 1978 | location = [[State Library of South Australia]], North Terrace, Adelaide | type = [[University art museums and galleries]] | visitors = | director = Fiona Salmon<ref>[http://www.flinders.edu.au/people/fiona.salmon Fiona Salmon] Flinders University</ref> | curator = | publictransit = | website = {{URL|http://www.flinders.edu.au/artmuseum/}} }} '''Flinders University Art Museum & City Gallery''' (FUAM) is preserving and developing the [[Flinders University]]’s historical and contemporary art collections.<ref>[http://community.history.sa.gov.au/flinders-university-art-museum-city-gallery Flinders University Art Museum & City Gallery] community website</ref>
The City Gallery which is located at the [[State Library of South Australia]] in [[North Terrace, Adelaide]], mounts up to eight exhibitions a year. The university collections may be viewed by appointment.<ref>[http://www.flinders.edu.au/artmuseum Flinders University Art Museum & City Gallery] University website</ref>
== Collections == The Collection covers four main areas:<ref>[http://www.flinders.edu.au/artmuseum/collections/ Collections]</ref> * Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander art<ref>[http://www.flinders.edu.au/artmuseum/collections/highlights/aboriginal-and-torres-strait-islander-collection.cfm Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Collection]</ref> * European prints * Post-object and Documentation<ref>[http://www.flinders.edu.au/artmuseum/collections/highlights/post-object-and-documentation-collection.cfm Post-object and Documentation Collection]</ref> * Australian political posters
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Fondazione Roberto Longhi''' is an institute established by [[Italy|Italian]] scholar Roberto Longhi, located on Via Benedetto Fortini in [[Florence]], [[Tuscany]], Italy.
==History== In [[Roberto Longhi]] 1971 left his [[library]], photograph collection, and [[art collection]] "for the benefit of future generations".
The headquarters is the villa "Il Tasso" which Longhi acquired in 1939. This villa was the residence of Longhi and his wife Lucia Lopresti (the writer [[Anna Banti]]). The Foundation's preferred sphere of interest is [[art history|art historical]] research. It also focuses on artists and specific artistic themes, including [[contemporary art]] and artists. The [[museum]] (''pinacoteca'') of the Foundation is open only to scholars and by appointment.
==Activities== The Foundation's activities include [[Art exhibition|art exhibit]]s, [[publication]]s, [[lesson]]s, [[:wikt:conference|conferences]], [[seminar]]s, and scholarly meetings. These meetings are organized on a periodic basis and are generally of an international and [[interdisciplinary]] nature.
Each year the Foundation grants a series of [[scholarship|fellowship]]s to young Italian and foreign scholars selected on the basis of a competition. Since 1971, 300 young scholars have been granted a fellowship by the Longhi Foundation. Many of them now work in renowned [[museum]]s or are professors in important Italian and foreign [[university|universities]].
==External links== *[http://www.fondazionelonghi.it/fondazione/index.php?lang=eng Website for Fondazione Roberto Longhi]
[[Category:Arts centres in Italy]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Florence]] [[Category:Arts foundations]] [[Category:Arts organisations based in Italy]] [[Category:Culture in Florence]] [[Category:Cultural organisations based in Italy]] [[Category:Foundations based in Italy]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1971]] [[Category:1971 establishments in Italy]]

revision.text:
The '''Future Library project''' ([[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]: ''Framtidsbiblioteket'') is a public artwork that aims to collect an original work by a popular writer every year from 2014 to 2114 and to share them with the world only then. One thousand trees were specially planted for the project in the [[Nordmarka]] forest at its inception<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/06/10/future-library_n_7532012.html|title='Future Library' Reminds Us How Connected Books And The Environment Really Are|website=The Huffington Post|accessdate=2015-08-09}}</ref>; the 100 books will be printed in limited-edition anthologies using paper made from the trees. ''[[The Guardian]]'' has referred to it as "the world's most secretive library".<ref name="kang">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/aug/31/han-kang-bury-book-100-years-norwegian-forest-future-library|title=Han Kang to bury next book for almost 100 years in Norwegian forest|first=Alison|last=Flood|publisher=The Guardian|date=2018-08-31|accessdate=2018-09-10}}</ref>
==History== The project was conceived by [[Katie Paterson]] during the summer of 2014. It is managed by the Future Library Trust and supported by the [[Oslo|City of Oslo]], [[Norway]]. It was produced for the Slow Space public art program and commissioned by [[Bjørvika]], Oslo's former container port, and its development corporation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.futurelibrary.no/|title=Future Library – Framtidsbiblioteket - Katie Paterson|page=About|accessdate=2015-08-09}}</ref>
The manuscripts will be held in a specially designed room at the new [[Oslo Public Library|Deichman Library]] (Oslo Public Library) currently under construction in Bjørvika, Oslo.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Reader offer: buy a Katie Paterson Future Library limited-edition print|url = https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/nov/23/reader-offer-katie-paterson-print-future-library|newspaper = the Guardian|date=November 23, 2014 |first = Vanessa|last = Thorpe}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = In English|url = http://blogg.deichman.no/nyedeichman/in-english/|accessdate = 2015-08-09}}</ref> Katie Paterson has been working with the architectural team to design this part of the new public library.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nothingintherulebook.com/2018/05/23/creatives-in-profile-interview-with-katie-paterson/|title=Creatives in profile – interview with Katie Paterson|date=2018-05-23|work=nothingintherulebook|access-date=2018-08-13|language=en-US}}</ref> The collected works will be on display but the manuscripts will not be available for reading.
The Future Library Trust's committee of trustees will make a new selection annually based on the criteria "outstanding contributions to literature or poetry, and for their work's ability to capture the imagination of this and future generations."<ref>{{Cite web|title = A library that won't be read for 100 years|url = http://www.mprnews.org/story/2015/05/29/books-thread-future-library|website = www.mprnews.org|accessdate = 2015-08-09|first = Tracy|last = Mumford}}</ref> [[Umberto Eco]] and [[Tomas Tranströmer]], both deceased as of 2016, were previously considered as potential contributors. All other authors approached by Paterson have accepted the invitation.<ref name="smh">{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/books/the-future-library-why-you-face-a-big-wait-to-read-any-of-the-books-20170113-gtqw6i.html|title=The Future Library: Why you face a big wait to read any of the books|first=Gaby|last=Wood|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=2017-01-13|accessdate=2018-09-10}}</ref>
One thousand certificates entitling the holder to the full anthology in 2114 are being sold by the artist's galleries: Ingleby Gallery (Edinburgh), James Cohan Gallery (New York) and Parafin (London). Initially sold for £625, the price increased to £800 in 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/nov/23/reader-offer-katie-paterson-print-future-library|title=Reader offer: buy a Katie Paterson Future Library limited-edition print|last=Thorpe|first=Vanessa|date=2014-11-23|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Future Library {{!}} Edition {{!}} Ingleby Gallery|url = http://www.inglebygallery.com/edition/future-library/|website = www.inglebygallery.com|accessdate = 2015-08-09}}</ref>
==Criticism== The Future Library project has attracted criticism for its emphasis on preventing readership between 2014 and 2114.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://maggietiede.com/2018/09/05/margaret-atwood-han-kang-and-more-will-bury-their-new-novels-for-100-years-what-do-you-think-about-the-future-library-project/|first=Maggie|last=Tiede|title=Margaret Atwood, Han Kang, and more will bury their new novels for 100 years. What do you think about the Future Library Project?|date=2018-09-05|accessdate=2018-09-10}}</ref> One of the few details known about the books was revealed accidentally when [[David Mitchell (author)|David Mitchell]] stated that his book quotes the lyrics of ''[[Here Comes The Sun]]'', a song expected to enter the [[public domain]] in the late 21st century.<ref name="smh" /> Writing for ''[[Flavorwire]]'', Moze Halperin called the project "art whose intention is to exclude a few generations" and criticized the class exclusivity planned for the works even after they are released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://flavorwire.com/574802/john-malkovichs-100-years-raises-important-questions-even-if-well-never-see-it|first=Moze|last=Halperin|title=John Malkovich’s Silly Cognac-Based ‘100 Years’ Project Raises Important Questions, Even If We’ll Never See It|publisher=Flavorwire|date=2016-05-06|accessdate=2018-09-10}}</ref>
==Contributors== The identity of each contributing author is announced yearly around October; they then submit their manuscripts to the collection the following spring. Current contributors to the collection are: *2014 – [[Margaret Atwood]], "''Scribbler Moon''", submitted 27 May 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/sep/05/margaret-atwood-new-work-unseen-century-future-library |title=Margaret Atwood's new work will remain unseen for a century |last=Flood |first=Alison |work=The Guardian |date=2014-09-05 |accessdate=2014-09-07}}</ref><ref>Alison Flood, [https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/may/27/margaret-atwood-scribbler-moon-future-library-norway-katie-paterson Into the woods: Margaret Atwood reveals her Future Library book, Scribbler Moon], The Guardian, 27 May 2015.</ref> *2015 – [[David Mitchell (author)|David Mitchell]], "''[[From Me Flows What You Call Time]]''", submitted 28 May 2016.<ref>{{cite web |first=Patrick |last=Clarke |url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/david-mitchell-buries-manuscript-future-library-project-330710 |title=David Mitchell buries manuscript for Future Library project |work=The Bookseller |date=May 31, 2016 }}</ref> *2016 – [[Sjón]], "''As My Brow Brushes On The Tunics Of Angels or The Drop Tower, the Roller Coaster, the Whirling Cups and other Instruments of Worship from the Post-Industrial Age''", submitted 2 June 2017.<ref>{{cite web |first=Katherine |last=Cowdrey |url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/icelandic-writer-sj-n-named-next-contributor-future-library-414176 |title=Icelandic writer Sjón named next Future Library contributor |work=The Bookseller |date=October 14, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Hovind|first1=Anne Beate|title=Join us as Sjón presents his manuscript to Future Library|url=http://mailchi.mp/8cc56510e03a/join-us-as-sjn-presents-his-manuscript-to-future-library-2301925|website=MailChimp|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> *2017 – [[Elif Shafak]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/oct/27/elif-shafak-joins-future-library-writing-piece-to-be-unveiled-in-2114|title=Elif Shafak joins Future Library, writing piece to be unveiled in 2114|last=Flood|first=Alison|date=2017-10-27|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>, "''The Last Taboo''", submitted 2 June 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.futurelibrary.no/#/news-and-media|title=Future Library Upcoming Events|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> *2018 – [[Han Kang]]<ref name="kang" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://futurelibrary.no}} * [http://katiepaterson.org/portfolio/future-library/ Artist's website for the project]
